speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: SCENE III. Court of TITUS's house. A banquet set out.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS, MARCUS, and Goths, with AARON prisoner

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Uncle Marcus, since it is my father's mind

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That I repair to Rome, I am content.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: And ours with thine, befall what fortune will.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Good uncle, take you in this barbarous Moor,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This ravenous tiger, this accursed devil;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let him receive no sustenance, fetter him

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Till he be brought unto the empress' face,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For testimony of her foul proceedings:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And see the ambush of our friends be strong;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I fear the emperor means no good to us.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Some devil whisper curses in mine ear,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And prompt me, that my tongue may utter forth

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The venomous malice of my swelling heart!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Away, inhuman dog! unhallow'd slave!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sirs, help our uncle to convey him in.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exeunt Goths, with AARON. Flourish within

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The trumpets show the emperor is at hand.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter SATURNINUS and TAMORA, with AEMILIUS, Tribunes, Senators, and others

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What, hath the firmament more suns than one?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: What boots it thee to call thyself a sun?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rome's emperor, and nephew, break the parle;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These quarrels must be quietly debated.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The feast is ready, which the careful Titus

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hath ordain'd to an honourable end,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For peace, for love, for league, and good to Rome:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Please you, therefore, draw nigh, and take your places.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Marcus, we will.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Hautboys sound. The Company sit down at table

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Enter TITUS dressed like a Cook, LAVINIA veiled,  Young LUCIUS, and others. TITUS places the dishes on the table

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Welcome, my gracious lord; welcome, dread queen;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Welcome, ye warlike Goths; welcome, Lucius;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And welcome, all: although the cheer be poor,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Twill fill your stomachs; please you eat of it.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Why art thou thus attired, Andronicus?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Because I would be sure to have all well,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To entertain your highness and your empress.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: We are beholding to you, good Andronicus.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: An if your highness knew my heart, you were.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My lord the emperor, resolve me this:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Was it well done of rash Virginius

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To slay his daughter with his own right hand,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Because she was enforced, stain'd, and deflower'd?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: It was, Andronicus.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Your reason, mighty lord?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Because the girl should not survive her shame,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And by her presence still renew his sorrows.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A reason mighty, strong, and effectual;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A pattern, precedent, and lively warrant,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For me, most wretched, to perform the like.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Die, die, Lavinia, and thy shame with thee;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kills LAVINIA

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, with thy shame, thy father's sorrow die!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What hast thou done, unnatural and unkind?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kill'd her, for whom my tears have made me blind.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I am as woful as Virginius was,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And have a thousand times more cause than he

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To do this outrage: and it now is done.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What, was she ravish'd? tell who did the deed.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will't please you eat? will't please your

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: highness feed?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why hast thou slain thine only daughter thus?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Not I; 'twas Chiron and Demetrius:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They ravish'd her, and cut away her tongue;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And they, 'twas they, that did her all this wrong.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Go fetch them hither to us presently.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, there they are both, baked in that pie;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whereof their mother daintily hath fed,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Eating the flesh that she herself hath bred.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Tis true, 'tis true; witness my knife's sharp point.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kills TAMORA

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Die, frantic wretch, for this accursed deed!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Kills TITUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Can the son's eye behold his father bleed?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: There's meed for meed, death for a deadly deed!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Kills SATURNINUS. A great tumult. LUCIUS, MARCUS, and others go up into the balcony

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You sad-faced men, people and sons of Rome,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: By uproar sever'd, like a flight of fowl

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Scatter'd by winds and high tempestuous gusts,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, let me teach you how to knit again

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This scatter'd corn  into one mutual sheaf,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These broken limbs again into one body;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lest Rome herself be bane unto herself,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And she whom mighty kingdoms court'sy to,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Like a forlorn and desperate castaway,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Do shameful execution on herself.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But if my frosty signs and chaps of age,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Grave witnesses of true experience,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Cannot induce you to attend my words,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To LUCIUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Speak, Rome's dear friend, as erst our ancestor,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When with his solemn tongue he did discourse

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To love-sick Dido's sad attending ear

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The story of that baleful burning night

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When subtle Greeks surprised King Priam's Troy,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tell us what Sinon hath bewitch'd our ears,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or who hath brought the fatal engine in

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That gives our Troy, our Rome, the civil wound.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My heart is not compact of flint nor steel;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Nor can I utter all our bitter grief,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But floods of tears will drown my oratory,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And break my utterance, even in the time

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When it should move you to attend me most,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lending your kind commiseration.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here is a captain, let him tell the tale;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Your hearts will throb and weep to hear him speak.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Then, noble auditory, be it known to you,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That cursed Chiron and Demetrius

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Were they that murdered our emperor's brother;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And they it were that ravished our sister:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For their fell faults our brothers were beheaded;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Our father's tears despised, and basely cozen'd

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Of that true hand that fought Rome's quarrel out,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And sent her enemies unto the grave.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Lastly, myself unkindly banished,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The gates shut on me, and turn'd weeping out,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To beg relief among Rome's enemies:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Who drown'd their enmity in my true tears.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And oped their arms to embrace me as a friend.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I am the turned forth, be it known to you,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That have preserved her welfare in my blood;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And from her bosom took the enemy's point,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sheathing the steel in my adventurous body.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Alas, you know I am no vaunter, I;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My scars can witness, dumb although they are,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That my report is just and full of truth.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But, soft! methinks I do digress too much,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Citing my worthless praise: O, pardon me;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For when no friends are by, men praise themselves.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now is my turn to speak. Behold this child:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Pointing to the Child in the arms of an Attendant

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Of this was Tamora delivered;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The issue of an irreligious Moor,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Chief architect and plotter of these woes:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The villain is alive in Titus' house,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And as he is, to witness this is true.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now judge what cause had Titus to revenge

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These wrongs, unspeakable, past patience,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or more than any living man could bear.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now you have heard the truth, what say you, Romans?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Have we done aught amiss,--show us wherein,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, from the place where you behold us now,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The poor remainder of Andronici

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will, hand in hand, all headlong cast us down.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And on the ragged stones beat forth our brains,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And make a mutual closure of our house.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Speak, Romans, speak; and if you say we shall,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lo, hand in hand, Lucius and I will fall.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Come, come, thou reverend man of Rome,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: And bring our emperor gently in thy hand,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Lucius our emperor; for well I know

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: The common voice do cry it shall be so.

speaker: All
text_entry: Lucius, all hail, Rome's royal emperor!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Go, go into old Titus' sorrowful house,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To Attendants

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And hither hale that misbelieving Moor,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To be adjudged some direful slaughtering death,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As punishment for his most wicked life.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt Attendants

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: LUCIUS, MARCUS, and the others descend

speaker: All
text_entry: Lucius, all hail, Rome's gracious governor!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Thanks, gentle Romans: may I govern so,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To heal Rome's harms, and wipe away her woe!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But, gentle people, give me aim awhile,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For nature puts me to a heavy task:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Stand all aloof: but, uncle, draw you near,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To shed obsequious tears upon this trunk.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O, take this warm kiss on thy pale cold lips,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Kissing TITUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: These sorrowful drops upon thy blood-stain'd face,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The last true duties of thy noble son!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tear for tear, and loving kiss for kiss,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thy brother Marcus tenders on thy lips:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O were the sum of these that I should pay

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Countless and infinite, yet would I pay them!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Come hither, boy; come, come, and learn of us

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To melt in showers: thy grandsire loved thee well:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Many a time he danced thee on his knee,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sung thee asleep, his loving breast thy pillow:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Many a matter hath he told to thee,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Meet and agreeing with thine infancy;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: In that respect, then, like a loving child,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Shed yet some small drops from thy tender spring,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Because kind nature doth require it so:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Friends should associate friends in grief and woe:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Bid him farewell; commit him to the grave;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Do him that kindness, and take leave of him.

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: O grandsire, grandsire! even with all my heart

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Would I were dead, so you did live again!

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: O Lord, I cannot speak to him for weeping;

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: My tears will choke me, if I ope my mouth.

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Re-enter Attendants with AARON

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: You sad Andronici, have done with woes:

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Give sentence on this execrable wretch,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: That hath been breeder of these dire events.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Set him breast-deep in earth, and famish him;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: There let him stand, and rave, and cry for food;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: If any one relieves or pities him,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For the offence he dies. This is our doom:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Some stay to see him fasten'd in the earth.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: O, why should wrath be mute, and fury dumb?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I am no baby, I, that with base prayers

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I should repent the evils I have done:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ten thousand worse than ever yet I did

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Would I perform, if I might have my will;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If one good deed in all my life I did,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I do repent it from my very soul.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Some loving friends convey the emperor hence,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And give him burial in his father's grave:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My father and Lavinia shall forthwith

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Be closed in our household's monument.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: As for that heinous tiger, Tamora,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No funeral rite, nor man m mourning weeds,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No mournful bell shall ring her burial;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But throw her forth to beasts and birds of prey:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Her life was beast-like, and devoid of pity;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And, being so, shall have like want of pity.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: See justice done on Aaron, that damn'd Moor,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: By whom our heavy haps had their beginning:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Then, afterwards, to order well the state,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That like events may ne'er it ruinate.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
